title._content: Dance band drummer at Mark Foy's Empress Ballroom

description._content: Format: Glass plate negative. Rights Info: No known restrictions on publication. Repository: Thomas Lennon Photographic Collection, Powerhouse Museum www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/collection=Thomas_Lennon_Photographic Part Of: Powerhouse Museum Collection General information about the Powerhouse Museum Collection is available at www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database Persistent URL: http://www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=388601

note._content: not so unbelievable, A1 Studio! This was the first kind of "sock cymbal" device that was invented, and these were in wide use for a few years before the appropriately named "high hat" (cause it was higher than these "low boys") was introduced.
note.author: 24184828@N08

note._content: Those are wood blocks, pyro-rockstar. They're sometimes called "temple blocks" or "Chinese temple blocks". They were a relatively standard item on drum sets of the time.
note.author: 24184828@N08

note._content: Weren´t these pre-hi-hat thingies also known as Charleston-machines?
note.author: 29262784@N02

note._content: Yes, T_P_a_E_ B, they were called "charleston" cymbals as well. I've never heard charleston "machine", but perhaps that was in use somewhere sometime.
note.author: 24184828@N08

note._content: This is an 18 inch wind gong.
note.author: 73039049@N00

note._content: I recognize this badge as Leedy Drum Co. Looks like a 10 lug broadway model snare drum.
note.author: 73039049@N00

note._content: I recognize this badge as Leedy Drum Co. It looks like a 10 lug Broadway model.
note.author: 73039049@N00

note._content: This appears to be an 18 or 20 inch wind gong.
note.author: 73039049@N00

note._content: These are hand carved wooden blocks made to look like stylized fish. They are Buddhist Temple Blocks, and were standard on all "deluxe" model drum sets from all the manufacturers from the 1930s to the 1950s. They were imported from Korea (Moktak), China (Muyu), or Japan (Mogyu). Forgive my spellings. I own three sets from the 30s. and use them in live and recorded scenarios regularly.
note.author: 73039049@N00

note._content: The snare its pretty uncomffortable as it is, well as for my style, but i dont think that much people use it like that anymore.
note.author: 8507166@N03

note._content: yes, Sakiel1087, that extreme tilted angle of the snare drum (a holdover from the position/playing technique in marching bands) is almost never seen these days.
note.author: 24184828@N08

note._content: Hunt Sales (Iggy Pop, Tin Machine, Todd Rundgren, etc.) performs w/ snaredrum like this too.
note.author: 42412671@N06

note._content: Actually no, Hunt Sales plays with a matched grip.  He tilts his snare forward, not to the side like this gentleman.
note.author: 40636053@N00
